article.description:
This time, Brian Boddicker and the rest of
the Texas reserves did everything right.
article.headline: Longhorns' bench rebounds against Baylor
article.linkText: Texas rips Baylor to stay in Big 12 title hunt
article.story: AUSTIN, Texas (AP) -- This time, Brian Boddicker and the rest of the Texas reserves did everything right. Boddicker came off the bench to score 19 points Wednesday night -- 16 in the first half -- as the (No. 6 ESPN/USA Today, No. 5 AP) Longhorns rebounded from a loss to Oklahoma State with an 82-64 win over Baylor that keeps them in the hunt for the Big 12 title. Coach Rick Barnes ripped his team after the Longhorns got only two points off the bench in a loss Saturday that cost Texas (19-5, 10-3) a share of the conference lead. The Longhorns are tied for second place, one game behind Kansas with three to play. Boddicker made sure he wouldn't have to hear those words again. The junior swingman hit three 3-pointers in the key first-half burst that put the game away early. Boddicker said he took the loss and the criticism from Barnes personally. "We all do. Our bench just didn't show up that game and we can't have that,'' Boddicker said. "We have to start putting it all together. "Tonight I was feeling pretty good.'' Jason Klotz gave Texas its first lead at 9-7 with a turnaround jumper and Sydmill Harris' 3-pointer started a 19-3 run that put the Longhorns well in control at 28-10 with 6:43 left in the first half. With Boddicker leading the way, Texas' reserves outscored the starters 21-17 in the first half. Baylor (13-11, 4-9) came in on a three-game winning streak but had a hard time finding any rhythm against the Texas defense, shooting just 7-of-34 in the first half. Lawrence Roberts, who led the Bears with 27 points, was 0-for-8 from the floor as Texas took a 38-19 lead into halftime. Barnes wanted even more in the second. "The strength of our success has been our `team,''' Barnes said. "That's what I talked to them about before we went back out. Let's see if we can have the best team effort we've had all year.'' Texas' starters picked up the scoring in the second. James Thomas started the half by finishing a pair of three-point plays, Royal Ivey hit a running bank shot and Brandon Mouton converted a three-point play on a two-handed dunk off the baseline to put Texas up 49-25. Roberts finally found his stroke in the second, hitting his first six shots of the half as the Bears closed the deficit to 68-52. But it was too little, too late. Mouton hit a short jumper and converted a three-point play off a fast-break assist from T.J. Ford as Texas quickly pushed the lead back over 20 at 72-51. Mouton finished with 16 points and Thomas had 15 points and 17 rebounds as Texas dominated the boards 51-36. Mouton, Ford and Thomas combined for 72 points in Texas' loss to Oklahoma State. Ford, who had a career-high 32 in that game, was content to let everyone else score against Baylor. The 'Horns' leading scorer this season finished with eight points to go with five assists. Baylor, which leads the Big 12 in 3-point shooting with more than nine per game, tried to catch up by bombing away from outside but was just 3-of-24 from the arc. "We just couldn't knock them down,'' said John Lucas, who scored 12 points for Baylor but missed all three of his 3-pointers. "They were playing good defense.'' Texas made a point of contesting the outside shot. "Our game plan was just to play the 3-point line and not give them any open looks,'' Thomas said.
